Situation1: Celebrate each other's achievements and milestones.
Expectation2: Fix bugs and troubleshoot issues reported by users or QA
Situation2: A production outage traces back to a defect in their code and customers cannot access the service
Story: My phone buzzed with a message from my sister: “Don’t forget, dinner’s at 7! Can’t wait to celebrate my promotion with you!” I smiled, proud of her, knowing how much this meant. As her brother, I wanted to be there, to cheer her on, to make her feel special. But just as I was about to shut down my laptop, a Slack notification popped up—urgent, all caps: “PRODUCTION OUTAGE. Users locked out. Root cause: your last commit.” My heart sank. The expectation was clear: as the developer responsible, I had to fix this, and fast. Customers were already complaining, and the team was counting on me. I stared at the clock, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in. My family expected my presence, my support. My team and our users needed my expertise, my immediate action. I felt torn, guilt gnawing at me no matter which way I turned. I sat frozen, caught between the celebration my sister deserved and the crisis my code had caused, unsure which role I could bear to let down.
